title: How to Make Crinkle Cut Chips

steps.headline: Peel and cut the potatoes.
steps.description: Wash 1.1 pounds (500 g) of starchy potatoes and use a vegetable peeler to remove the skin. Take a crinkle cut tool and slice each potato into 1/3-inch (8-mm) thick slices. Lay each slice flat and then use the tool to slice them into long strips. Cut them as wide as you'd like the chips to be. For starchy potatoes, consider using Russets, King Edwards, or Up-to-dates. Keep in mind that skinny crinkle cut chips will fry faster than wider ones.

steps.headline: Heat the oil in a wok until it's at 260 °F (127 °C).
steps.description: Measure 1 1/2 cups (10 ounces (355 ml) of beef tallow, lard, or peanut oil into a wok or large frying pan with high sides. Turn the heat to medium-high and attach a deep fry thermometer on the side of the wok or pan. Heat the oil until it reaches 260 °F (127 °C). If you don't have a deep fry thermometer, you can test if the oil is hot enough by dropping a breadcrumb in the oil. If it takes 10 to 20 seconds before the breadcrumb sizzles, the oil is hot enough.

steps.headline: Place half of the crinkle cut chips in the oil and fry them for 3 to 5 minutes.
steps.description: Slowly lower about half of the crinkle cut chips in the hot oil and stir them occasionally. Fry the crinkle cut chips until they become soft but not brown. This should take 3 to 5 minutes.

steps.headline: Remove the chips and fry the other batch.
steps.description: Lay a paper towel on a plate next to the wok. Use a slotted spoon to lift the fried chips out of the oil and onto the paper towel-lined plate. Heat the oil back up to 260 °F (127 °C) and add the rest of the crinkle cut chips. Fry them for 3 to 5 minutes, so they become soft.

steps.headline: Heat the oil between 350 °F (177 °C) and 375 °F (191 °C).
steps.description: Remove the last batch of chips from the oil and set them on the paper towel to drain. Heat the oil over medium-high heat until it reaches between 375 °F (191 °C) and 375 °F (191 °C). If you're not using a deep fry thermometer, the oil will be hot enough if you drop a breadcrumb into the oil and it sizzles immediately.

steps.headline: Fry half of the chips for 5 to 7 minutes.
steps.description: Once the oil is hot, slowly lower half of the chips from the paper-towel lined plate into the oil. Stir the chips every once in a while as they fry, so they cook evenly. Fry the chips until they're golden brown. This should take 5 to 7 minutes.

steps.headline: Remove the chips and fry the other batch.
steps.description: Lay a new paper towel on another plate and use a slotted spoon to lift the crispy crinkle cut chips out of the oil. Drain them on the plate while the oil heats back up. Fry the rest of the chips for 5 to 7 minutes, so they become crisp and golden brown.

steps.headline: Season the crinkle cut chips and serve them.
steps.description: Sprinkle a generous amount of salt over the fried chips and toss them a little to evenly coat them. Serve the chips while they're still hot. Avoid storing the crinkle cut chips because they will become soggy as they sit.

steps.headline: Preheat the oven and prepare a baking sheet.
steps.description: Turn the oven on to 400 °F (204 °C). Get out a rimmed baking sheet and spread 2 tablespoons of the oil across the bottom of the sheet. The oil will prevent the chips from sticking and help them crisp up as they bake. Set the sheet aside. You can use canola, vegetable, or peanut oil.

steps.headline: Peel and cut the chips.
steps.description: Wash 3 large or 6 medium baking potatoes and use a vegetable peeler to remove the skins. Take a crinkle cut tool and cut the potatoes into 1/3-inch (8-mm) thick slices. Lay the slices flat and cut them into strips as wide as you'd like.

steps.headline: Soak the chips in salty water for 10 minutes.
steps.description: Get out a bowl large enough to hold the chips. Fill the bowl three-quarters of the way full with cold water. Stir in enough salt to make the water cloudy. Add the crinkle cut chips and submerge them in the salty water for 10 minutes. For example, if you used about 4 cups (0.9 liter) of water, you should add about 1/2 cup (150 g) of salt.

steps.headline: Drain and dry the crinkle cut chips.
steps.description: Lay paper towels across a large plate. Lift the chips out of the salty water and lay them on the paper towels. Blot the chips until they're dry.

steps.headline: Combine the seasoning mix.
steps.description:
Get out a large bowl and measure 1/2 cup (50 g) of grated Parmesan cheese into it. Stir in the rest of the seasonings until they're combined. You'll need:
1/2 teaspoon (1 g) paprika
1/4 teaspoon (1.5 g) seasoning salt
1/4 teaspoon (1.5 g) salt
1 teaspoon (0.5 g) fresh basil
1/2 teaspoon (1 g) garlic powder

steps.headline: Spread the seasoning over the chips arrange them on the sheet.
steps.description: Place the dried crinkle cut chips in the bowl with the seasoning mix and toss them until the potatoes are coated. Spread the chips evenly across the prepared baking sheet so they're in a single layer. Drizzle the last 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of oil over the potatoes.

steps.headline: Bake the seasoned crinkle cut chips for 25 to 30 minutes.
steps.description: Place the baking sheet in the oven and bake the potatoes until they become crisp and golden brown. This should take about 25 to 30 minutes. Serve the chips while they're still hot. Avoid storing the baked crinkle cut chips because they'll become soggy as they sit.

text:
Frying Crinkle Cut Chips Peel and cut the potatoes. Wash 1.1 pounds (500 g) of starchy potatoes and use a vegetable peeler to remove the skin. Take a crinkle cut tool and slice each potato into 1/3-inch (8-mm) thick slices. Lay each slice flat and then use the tool to slice them into long strips. Cut them as wide as you'd like the chips to be. For starchy potatoes, consider using Russets, King Edwards, or Up-to-dates. Keep in mind that skinny crinkle cut chips will fry faster than wider ones. Heat the oil in a wok until it's at 260 °F (127 °C). Measure 1 1/2 cups (10 ounces (355 ml) of beef tallow, lard, or peanut oil into a wok or large frying pan with high sides. Turn the heat to medium-high and attach a deep fry thermometer on the side of the wok or pan. Heat the oil until it reaches 260 °F (127 °C). If you don't have a deep fry thermometer, you can test if the oil is hot enough by dropping a breadcrumb in the oil. If it takes 10 to 20 seconds before the breadcrumb sizzles, the oil is hot enough. Place half of the crinkle cut chips in the oil and fry them for 3 to 5 minutes. Slowly lower about half of the crinkle cut chips in the hot oil and stir them occasionally. Fry the crinkle cut chips until they become soft but not brown. This should take 3 to 5 minutes. Remove the chips and fry the other batch. Lay a paper towel on a plate next to the wok. Use a slotted spoon to lift the fried chips out of the oil and onto the paper towel-lined plate. Heat the oil back up to 260 °F (127 °C) and add the rest of the crinkle cut chips. Fry them for 3 to 5 minutes, so they become soft. Heat the oil between 350 °F (177 °C) and 375 °F (191 °C). Remove the last batch of chips from the oil and set them on the paper towel to drain. Heat the oil over medium-high heat until it reaches between 375 °F (191 °C) and 375 °F (191 °C). If you're not using a deep fry thermometer, the oil will be hot enough if you drop a breadcrumb into the oil and it sizzles immediately. Fry half of the chips for 5 to 7 minutes. Once the oil is hot, slowly lower half of the chips from the paper-towel lined plate into the oil. Stir the chips every once in a while as they fry, so they cook evenly. Fry the chips until they're golden brown. This should take 5 to 7 minutes. Remove the chips and fry the other batch. Lay a new paper towel on another plate and use a slotted spoon to lift the crispy crinkle cut chips out of the oil. Drain them on the plate while the oil heats back up. Fry the rest of the chips for 5 to 7 minutes, so they become crisp and golden brown. Season the crinkle cut chips and serve them. Sprinkle a generous amount of salt over the fried chips and toss them a little to evenly coat them. Serve the chips while they're still hot. Avoid storing the crinkle cut chips because they will become soggy as they sit. Baking Crinkle Cut Chips Preheat the oven and prepare a baking sheet. Turn the oven on to 400 °F (204 °C). Get out a rimmed baking sheet and spread 2 tablespoons of the oil across the bottom of the sheet. The oil will prevent the chips from sticking and help them crisp up as they bake. Set the sheet aside. You can use canola, vegetable, or peanut oil. Peel and cut the chips. Wash 3 large or 6 medium baking potatoes and use a vegetable peeler to remove the skins. Take a crinkle cut tool and cut the potatoes into 1/3-inch (8-mm) thick slices. Lay the slices flat and cut them into strips as wide as you'd like. Soak the chips in salty water for 10 minutes. Get out a bowl large enough to hold the chips. Fill the bowl three-quarters of the way full with cold water. Stir in enough salt to make the water cloudy. Add the crinkle cut chips and submerge them in the salty water for 10 minutes. For example, if you used about 4 cups (0.9 liter) of water, you should add about 1/2 cup (150 g) of salt. Drain and dry the crinkle cut chips. Lay paper towels across a large plate. Lift the chips out of the salty water and lay them on the paper towels. Blot the chips until they're dry. Combine the seasoning mix. Get out a large bowl and measure 1/2 cup (50 g) of grated Parmesan cheese into it. Stir in the rest of the seasonings until they're combined. You'll need:
1/2 teaspoon (1 g) paprika
1/4 teaspoon (1.5 g) seasoning salt
1/4 teaspoon (1.5 g) salt
1 teaspoon (0.5 g) fresh basil
1/2 teaspoon (1 g) garlic powder Spread the seasoning over the chips arrange them on the sheet. Place the dried crinkle cut chips in the bowl with the seasoning mix and toss them until the potatoes are coated. Spread the chips evenly across the prepared baking sheet so they're in a single layer. Drizzle the last 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of oil over the potatoes. Bake the seasoned crinkle cut chips for 25 to 30 minutes. Place the baking sheet in the oven and bake the potatoes until they become crisp and golden brown. This should take about 25 to 30 minutes. Serve the chips while they're still hot. Avoid storing the baked crinkle cut chips because they'll become soggy as they sit.
sentences: Frying Crinkle Cut Chips Peel and cut the potatoes.
Wash 1.1 pounds (500 g) of starchy potatoes and use a vegetable peeler to remove the skin.
Take a crinkle cut tool and slice each potato into 1/3-inch (8-mm) thick slices.
Lay each slice flat and then use the tool to slice them into long strips.
Cut them as wide as you'd like the chips to be.
For starchy potatoes, consider using Russets, King Edwards, or Up-to-dates.
Keep in mind that skinny crinkle cut chips will fry faster than wider ones.
Heat the oil in a wok until it's at 260 °F (127 °C).
Measure 1 1/2 cups (10 ounces (355 ml) of beef tallow, lard, or peanut oil into a wok or large frying pan with high sides.
Turn the heat to medium-high and attach a deep fry thermometer on the side of the wok or pan.
Heat the oil until it reaches 260 °F (127 °C).
If you don't have a deep fry thermometer, you can test if the oil is hot enough by dropping a breadcrumb in the oil.
If it takes 10 to 20 seconds before the breadcrumb sizzles, the oil is hot enough.
Place half of the crinkle cut chips in the oil and fry them for 3 to 5 minutes.
Slowly lower about half of the crinkle cut chips in the hot oil and stir them occasionally.
Fry the crinkle cut chips until they become soft but not brown.
This should take 3 to 5 minutes.
Remove the chips and fry the other batch.
Lay a paper towel on a plate next to the wok.
Use a slotted spoon to lift the fried chips out of the oil and onto the paper towel-lined plate.
Heat the oil back up to 260 °F (127 °C) and add the rest of the crinkle cut chips.
Fry them for 3 to 5 minutes, so they become soft.
Heat the oil between 350 °F (177 °C) and 375 °F (191 °C).
Remove the last batch of chips from the oil and set them on the paper towel to drain.
Heat the oil over medium-high heat until it reaches between 375 °F (191 °C) and 375 °F (191 °C).
If you're not using a deep fry thermometer, the oil will be hot enough if you drop a breadcrumb into the oil and it sizzles immediately.
Fry half of the chips for 5 to 7 minutes.
Once the oil is hot, slowly lower half of the chips from the paper-towel lined plate into the oil.
Stir the chips every once in a while as they fry, so they cook evenly.
Fry the chips until they're golden brown.
This should take 5 to 7 minutes.
Remove the chips and fry the other batch.
Lay a new paper towel on another plate and use a slotted spoon to lift the crispy crinkle cut chips out of the oil.
Drain them on the plate while the oil heats back up.
Fry the rest of the chips for 5 to 7 minutes, so they become crisp and golden brown.
Season the crinkle cut chips and serve them.
Sprinkle a generous amount of salt over the fried chips and toss them a little to evenly coat them.
Serve the chips while they're still hot.
Avoid storing the crinkle cut chips because they will become soggy as they sit.
Baking Crinkle Cut Chips Preheat the oven and prepare a baking sheet.
Turn the oven on to 400 °F (204 °C).
Get out a rimmed baking sheet and spread 2 tablespoons of the oil across the bottom of the sheet.
The oil will prevent the chips from sticking and help them crisp up as they bake.
Set the sheet aside.
You can use canola, vegetable, or peanut oil.
Peel and cut the chips.
Wash 3 large or 6 medium baking potatoes and use a vegetable peeler to remove the skins.
Take a crinkle cut tool and cut the potatoes into 1/3-inch (8-mm) thick slices.
Lay the slices flat and cut them into strips as wide as you'd like.
Soak the chips in salty water for 10 minutes.
Get out a bowl large enough to hold the chips.
Fill the bowl three-quarters of the way full with cold water.
Stir in enough salt to make the water cloudy.
Add the crinkle cut chips and submerge them in the salty water for 10 minutes.
For example, if you used about 4 cups (0.9 liter) of water, you should add about 1/2 cup (150 g) of salt.
Drain and dry the crinkle cut chips.
Lay paper towels across a large plate.
Lift the chips out of the salty water and lay them on the paper towels.
Blot the chips until they're dry.
Combine the seasoning mix.
Get out a large bowl and measure 1/2 cup (50 g) of grated Parmesan cheese into it.
Stir in the rest of the seasonings until they're combined.

You'll need:
1/2 teaspoon (1 g) paprika
1/4 teaspoon (1.5 g) seasoning salt
1/4 teaspoon (1.5 g) salt
1 teaspoon (0.5 g) fresh basil
1/2 teaspoon (1 g) garlic powder Spread the seasoning over the chips arrange them on the sheet.
Place the dried crinkle cut chips in the bowl with the seasoning mix and toss them until the potatoes are coated.
Spread the chips evenly across the prepared baking sheet so they're in a single layer.
Drizzle the last 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of oil over the potatoes.
Bake the seasoned crinkle cut chips for 25 to 30 minutes.
Place the baking sheet in the oven and bake the potatoes until they become crisp and golden brown.
This should take about 25 to 30 minutes.
Serve the chips while they're still hot.
Avoid storing the baked crinkle cut chips because they'll become soggy as they sit.
tyn_section: Baked and Seasoned Crinkle Cut Chips
